fields.description:
The stop_crowd.sh script does, when executed, not kill the the actual java process. It leaves it it some sort of zombie state - still active, but unresponsive.

It seems to be related to the catalina.pid not being set on startup. 

If one however defines an environment variable CATALINA_PID=/opt/atlassian/crowd/latest/apache-tomcat/work/catalina.pid (or the location where tomcat expects the pid-file) the pid-file is created upon startup and stop_crowd.sh works as desired.

Resolution: CATALINA_PID should be set by default.
fields.summary: CROWD stop_crowd.sh script does not kill actua JAVA process

fields.description:
Derived from JRA-42343:

*Steps to reproduce (in JIRA)*
# Set a User Directory Read Only with Local Groups and synchronize it
# Add a local group to an LDAP user
# Change the User Directory permission to Read/Write or Read Only
# User still is a member of all the groups he was before
# Log in with the LDAP user

*Actual behaviour*
User loses his local groups after the login attempt

*Expected behaviour (Read only)*
User should lose his local groups after the User Directory permission is synchronized with the new permission
*Expected behaviour (Read/Write)*
Either the groups should be lost when the permission is synchronized with the new permission or the groups should remain after the login attempt and added to the LDAP server

If we try to remove the local group after changing the permission we get an error on screen.
{noformat}

fields.summary: Local groups are not removed on sync when local group support is disabled

fields.description: While Crowd supports BCRYPT for Internal database types, it's not currently possible to select BCRYPT as the LDAP hashing algorithm, despite the fact that some LDAP servers support it.
fields.summary: LDAP BCRYPT

Make it possible to configure the Crowd server to serve a customisable {{Cache-Control}} header with the session token resource, i.e., the response to these two operations:

fields.description:
Hi,

Crowd fails to retrieve the user after some operations as Create / Edit and groups change when the user as in its username @.
As example if you try to update a user with username 'john.doe@email.com', after hitting 'Update' the page shows "User <john.doe%40email.com'> does not exist.

+The url for the page is :+
https://crowdauth.netrefer.com/crowd/console/secure/user/view.action?directoryID=32769&updateSuccessful=true&name=john.doe%2540email.com

+If you edit the url like below:+
https://crowdauth.netrefer.com/crowd/console/secure/user/view.action?directoryID=32769&updateSuccessful=true&name=john.doe@email.com

The page is returned without any error.

Thanks,
fields.summary: Using emails on usernames fails when retrieving user after Create / Edit Operation

fields.description:
I would like very much to see extended LDAP attributes supported in future Crowd versions.

Currently, Crowd (and all the tied-in Atlassian applications like JIRA, Confluence and Bamboo) have to rely on user to enter their attributes in the database by themselves. But why bother if we (usually) already have them in our LDAP directories?

The usual attributes we're using at our company are:
* telephoneNumber
* mobile (That's for the cell phone, obviously)
* jpegPhoto
* title (Job Title)
* manager (that's for the person's immediate supervisor)

I'm sure there will be other people that'd like very much for Crowd/JIRA/Confluence to support this, as entering that manually was always an unneeded and cumbersome task.
Anyway, thank you for your time Atlassian, you're doing a great work!
fields.summary: Support extended LDAP attributes in Crowd/JIRA/Confluence

fields.description: Updating to the latest version will allow us to provide the documentation and severity fields that health checks are supposed to have.
fields.summary: Update Crowd to use the latest version of atlassian-healthcheck

fields.description: I want to write Python programs that consume the [Crowd REST resources|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/CROWDDEV/Crowd+REST+Resources]. I want to be abstracted from the HTTP dialog and the XML/JSON serialisation of the entities. I want an idiomatic API with error management.
fields.summary: As an application developer, I want to have an easy to use Python client for the Crowd REST API

fields.description: As an admin, I want to have a "panic button" that I can press when I suspect that the permissions (memberships) have been tampered with. This button should adjust the permissions in such way that anyone (else) that may have escalated to an admin will lose the privileges. When I press the button, I assume that I'll have to do some manual work to grant privileges again to legit admins.
fields.summary: As an admin, I want to restore the admin permissions to a "secure" state

fields.description:
As an admin, I have an UI in Crowd server to expire a single user session, and REST APIs to expire a single session (by session token & by username). What I would like to have is a UI and a REST API to bulk expire sessions:
* For a single username or email.
* For a set of usernames or emails.
* All the sessions.
fields.summary: As an admin, I want to bulk-expire SSO sessions

fields.description:
As an admin, I want to bulk expire passwords for users to force them to change their passwords before they can log in again.

I want to:
* Expire the password for a single user, identified by username or email.
* Expire the passwords for a set of users, identified by a list of usernames or emails.
* Expire the password for all the users of a directory.

Ideally I want to have a UI to easily perform this operation, and a REST API in case I need to automate it.

Optionally, users who have their passwords expired should receive an email notification (tracked as CWD-1765).
fields.summary: As an admin, I want to bulk-expire user passwords

fields.description:
When syncing large numbers of users or groups from a remote directory, Crowd loads all updated users in memory when updating the cache, which can lead to {{OutOfMemoryError}}s.

All {{CacheRefresher}} implementations seem to follow the same pattern:

* retrieve _all_ (updated) users from the remote directory
* for each user that needs to be added - create a new Crowd user in memory
* for each user that needs to be updated - create a new Crowd user in memory
* bulk create / update / delete the Crowd users in database.

A similar pattern is followed for the groups. If the remote directory has many users or groups, Crowd sync can use a lot of memory. We've seen 175 Mb in use in a Stash support case where an {{OutOfMemoryError}} was triggered.

The logic in the various CacheRefreshers should be updated to fetch a limited number of users/groups at a time (say 5000), process those and then move on to the next batch.
fields.summary: (Embedded) Crowd can run out of memory when syncing large numbers of groups and/or users

fields.description:
Two methods in {{DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations}} use {{contains}} on collections that aren't instances of {{Set}}; this could make the operations slower than necessary.

The methods are {{findUserMembershipForGroupChanges}} and {{findGroupMembershipForGroupChanges}}, and the objects are the {{internal}}/{{remote}} collections transformed within those methods.
fields.summary: DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations methods to find membership changes use List.contains check inside a loop

fields.description:
The new {{/openid/v2}} server silently permits authentication for any relying parties on a whitelist, for cases where services are considered part of the same system.

It would be good to also introduce the behaviour (present in the old server) of allowing users to confirm, for sites not on that list, that they want to authenticate. At it simplest, this would be a request for confirmation that did not persist.
fields.summary: Allow users to confirm authentication with the new /v2 OpenID server

fields.description:
When Crowd has many internal groups managing many different applications, it would be beneficial to allow the Crowd Administrator a way to filter the application to just the Crowd groups that are useful per application. For example, client has Confluence, JIRA, Fisheye, Bamboo and Stash, but Crowd is syncing all groups to the Confluence application as it can not filter the internal groups within Crowd per-application. 

Making this change would allow the admins to sync only the relevant groups to the relevant applications as required and ease pain with sync times.
fields.summary: Allow Crowd to filter its own internal Groups

fields.description: When using SSO, participating applications can decide to cache positive token validations for a while (implemented in CrowdAuthenticator). The only way to invalidate that cache is to restart the application.
fields.summary: As an admin of an application using SSO, I want to expire the token validation cache without downtime

fields.description:
The current logging sometimes creates unnecessary alarm or is not very informative.

Tune the logging levels, improve the logging messages and avoid unnecessary stacktraces.
fields.summary: Improve logging of directory synchronisation

fields.description:
When you add a user to a group, then we first must make sure the group exists.

But we do this check against the cached value, and this means that the answer can be wrong with bad results.
fields.summary: When adding a user membership to a caching remote directory errors can occur if the cache is stale.

fields.description:
*Note: This hasn't been replicated locally by Atlassian yet, but has been raised by multiple customers. If you have hit this issue and can provide steps to reproduce, please add them as a comment on this bug.*

When an application is configured in Crowd to with a password that included a non-alphanumeric character, users that should have access to the admin consoles of the client application consoles are denied access. 

The Crowd logs contain the following:

{code}2014-09-20 12:55:13,872 http-bio-8095-exec-19 INFO [plugin.rest.filter.BasicApplicationAuthenticationFilter] Invalid authentication for application with name 'conf'{code}

*Suspected Steps to Reproduce:*
# Setup Crowd with SSO enabled
# Setup Confluence (or JIRA etc) to use Crowd (with SSO enabled). Use a special character in the application password.
# Sign in to Confluence with an admin user and attempt to log into the admin console
_Note: This problem seems to occur after some time. The admin access will work for a while before failing._
fields.summary: special characters (@, $, & etc) in the application password causes the client application to not provide admin rights when using SSO

fields.description:
It's not currently possible to make configuration changes to a Delegated directory and have those changes take effect without first removing users. This adds unnecessary work because the Crowd administrator would then have to recreate local group memberships. 

h5. Steps to Reproduce
# Set up a delegated directory in Crowd against Apache Directory Studio 1.5
# On the Configuration screen, set "User display name attribute" to the "mail" attribute
# Create a Confluence application that uses that directory
# In Confluence, add that Crowd directory and log in as a user from that directory. The user will get added to the {{cwd_user}} table in both Confluence and Crowd, and will show the email address as the display name.
# In Crowd, edit the configuration of that delegated directory by setting "User display name attribute" to the default "displayName" attribute
# In Confluence, log in as that user again

h5. Expected Result

The user will now show the displayName from Apache as the display name.

h5. Actual Result

The user's display name still shows their email address. The display name in Crowd and Confluence will not be updated unless the user is removed first in Crowd and the user logs in to Confluence again, which basically recreates the user.
fields.summary: Allow configuration changes on a Delegated directory to be applied

fields.description: "Request Smuggling CVE-2014-0227" was fixed in Tomcat 7.0.55 as crowd currently seems to bundle tomcat 7.0.54 crowd is vulnerable to CVE-2014-0227.
fields.summary: Upgrade tomcat to a version >= 7.0.55

fields.description: It would great if Crowd have an application navigator like other Atlassian products. The application navigator we are talking about is described in the link [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Creating+Links+in+the+Application+Navigator].
fields.summary: implement application navigator for Crowd

fields.description:
Crowd default group memberships are suddenly lost on incremental sync and they do not get back. 

Only a fully sync does bring the memberships back but we cannot afford to run  a full sync every hour on LDAP directory with 16.000 accounts.

This is the 2nd time when this problem occurs and now I am sure that this is caused by some communication delays or packages being lost. 

Still this is unacceptable for any synchronization, group membership changes must be atomic, never start to remove/add groups till the server response does not end. Performing sync operations on partial LDAP results is a recipe for failures, like this one for example.
fields.summary: Crowd default group memberships are suddenly lost on incremental sync

fields.description: Adding a cert to the keystore is a somewhat painful process. A browser does this automatically.  It'd be nice to add an SSL cert to the keystore programatically through Crowd.
fields.summary: Add automatic detection of SSL subscriptions
Why is it now necessary for SSL to exist in the Java keystore on the Confluence server

fields.description:
Would be helpful to match the Username field width to match the Email Address field width. 

It's very common to use email also as Username. Also in integrations this is even a prerequisite.
fields.summary: Extend Username field to match Email Address field

fields.description: This would allow us to find which user corresponds to a particular key in environments with restricted access to the REST API/database.
fields.summary: Allow searching for user by key from admin interface

{{curl -X DELETE http://localhost:8095/crowd/rest/usermanagement/1/user/password?username=<username> -uappname:apppass}} to set a user's password to a value which causes password-based authentication to always fail (which in Crowd is {{PasswordCredential#NONE}}).
fields.summary: Allow setting a user's password to PC.NONE via REST API

fields.description:
Automatic user synchronization from a remote directory (when a Synchronisation Interval is set) stops working when manual Synchronisation is run.

*Steps to Reproduce*
# Configure a remote directory (Crowd or LDAP)
# Define a Synchronisation Interval (e.g. 5 minutes).
# Check it is running according to schedule.
# Click *Synchronise now*.
# Wait for the Synchronisation Interval again. It won't run.

*Workaround*

To have it working again, it is necessary to Edit the User Directory and set the Synchronisation Interval again.
fields.summary: Automatic user synchronization stops if manual synchronization is performed

fields.description:
User's names can be mixed with _Firstname + Lastname_ and _Lastname + Firstname_.
I will be happy if name display order can be changed by each user.

In 'cwd_user' table, 'display_name' field is fixed to _Lastname + Firstname_.
I've resolve this issue with a below query:
bq. {{"UPDATE cwd_user SET display_name=CONCAT(first_name,' ',last_name),lower_display_name=CONCAT(lower_first_name,' ',lower_last_name) WHERE user_name='user'"}}
fields.summary: Display name ordering

fields.description:
The entity tag for membership requests (CWD-4037) can result in requests that take longer before the header is served.

Add more logging,  to include:

- DEBUG logging of how long handling the request took
- INFO logging of long-running overall requests and memberships of specific groups
- DEBUG logging if an entity tag is being generated
fields.summary: Improve logging around memberships requests

fields.description:
The Crowd Oracle Documentation https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Oracle is incomplete as it does not provide the explanation on the that need to be granted to the user and the command that needed to be ran to create the database.

Since the database setup of  Confluence and Crowd is the same, it is possible to use the Oracle database guide from Confluence for now.
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Database+Setup+for+Oracle
fields.summary: Improvement on Crowd Oracle Database Guide

fields.description: Some application configuration (e.g., whether membership aggregation is on) is not included in the support information.
fields.summary: Include all the application configuration in the support information

fields.description:
There has been a few support cases being raised because users are not able to connect to an external User Directory using a outbound proxy.
https://support.atlassian.com/browse/SSP-6341

A stash defect has been raised because of this restriction.
https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-5501

h4. Steps to reproduce
# Set up Stash using an outbound proxy. Stash is set to go through Charles proxy setup in the same machine with the following parameter, nonproxyhost is *unset* to force all connection through the proxy:
{noformat}-Dhttp.proxyHost=localhost -Dhttp.proxyPort=8888 -Dhttps.proxyHost=localhost -Dhttps.proxyPort=8888{noformat}
# Add a Crowd Directory in Stash

h4. Expected Results
The request should go through the outgoing proxy set

h4. Actual Results
The request bypasses the proxy. This is proven by the absence of the request from Charles proxy logging. All other connection such as UPM and Application link goes through the proxy, as in Charles proxy logs:
fields.summary: Crowd ignores networking system properties

fields.description: {{org.springframework.ldap.core.DistinguishedName}} has been deprecated since CWD-3824; stop using it as part of normalising DNs.
fields.summary: Use LdapName in DNStandardiser

fields.description:
Content Anonymiser for Crowd data backup should be implemented for customers' private and confidential data, in accordance to Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA) policies.

Reference: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Content+Anonymiser+for+Data+Backups
fields.summary: Content Anonymiser for Crowd Data Backup

fields.description:
*Steps to Reproduce:*
# Configure a Crowd Internal Directory with two groups: confluence-users and jira-users. 
# Add two users: one a member of confluence-users, the other a member of jira-users.
# Set just confluence-users as a mapped group
# Connect this directory to Confluence. Confluence will now have all the groups from Crowd visible in it's user management admin pages. 
# Add the 'can use' global permission to the jira-users group from within Confluence

*Expected Results:*
Because jira-users isn't a mapped group, the member of this group should not be able to authenticate, even though jira-users has the 'can use' permission.

*Actual Results:*
the jira-users member is able to authenticate.
fields.summary: Users not in mapped groups are still able to authenticate

fields.description: We can document how users can enable SSLv3 but we should disable SSLv3 in the commented out tomcat TLS configuration, so as to prevent customers being vulnerable to POODLE.
fields.summary: Disable SSLv3 in the commented out TLS tomcat configuration

fields.description:
The [documentation|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/CROWDDEV/Crowd+REST+Resources#CrowdRESTResources-CrowdSSOTokenResource] claims that for an Inactive user, a 403 Forbidden is returned, but Crowd actually returns 400 Bad Request. We should change one or the other.

Example: 
{code}

http_proxy= curl -X POST http://localhost:4990/crowd/rest/usermanagement/1/session -H 'Content-Type: application/xml' --data '<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<authentication-context>
  <username>bob</username>
  <password>PASS</password>
</authentication-context>' -u CREDENTIALS -D-

{code}
Returns:
{code}

HTTP/1.1 400 Bad Request
Server: Apache-Coyote/1.1
Set-Cookie: JSESSIONID=793AFD463E34B00C3C18F7670F1CDE97; Path=/crowd; Secure; HttpOnly
X-Embedded-Crowd-Version: Horde/2.9.0-OD-054
targetFilterLifecycle: true
Content-Type: application/xml
Content-Length: 163
Date: Thu, 15 Jan 2015 04:03:48 GMT
Connection: close

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?><error><reason>INACTIVE_ACCOUNT</reason><message>Account with name <bob> is inactive</message></error>

{code}
fields.summary: Response of POST /session for inactive users does not match documentation

fields.description:
The Crowd Query Language allows searching by updateDate and creationDate.  

However, the API does not tell us the value of these fields.

https://developer.atlassian.com/display/CROWDDEV/Crowd+Query+Language
fields.summary: REST api should report CreationDate and UpdateDate

fields.description:
As per CWD-3593, it's not possible to use local groups with remote groups when working with a Delegated Authentication Directory.

In CWD-3389, this was added to Connector directories to allow this functionality, but it still doesn't exist for Delegated Auth directories.

As with CWD-3593, we should relax this restriction if it's simple enough to do so.
fields.summary: Allow remote groups as children of local groups when managing groups locally and using Delegated Authentication

fields.description:
*Scenario:*

A large firm has 40,000 users in their LDAP. They are using Crowd to manage these users. They have Confluence, JIRA and Stash connected to Crowd. Only 2,000 of these users have access to Stash, but all 40,000 of them appear in the user management areas of Stash. 

Also, if a directory is read only, then these users without access cannot be modified at all.
fields.summary: Provide an option to hide users in client applications if they do not have use permissions

fields.description:
Even after following https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWDKB/Change+password+email+have+wrong+base+url, changing *all* the following files, and restarting the server, it still is sending emails anchored at http://localhost:8095.

{code}
$ find /opt/atlassian/crowd/ -name crowd.properties/opt/atlassian/crowd/etc/crowd.properties
/opt/atlassian/crowd/crowd-openidserver-webapp/WEB-INF/classes/crowd.properties
/opt/atlassian/crowd/demo-src/crowd.properties
/opt/atlassian/crowd/demo-webapp/WEB-INF/classes/crowd.properties
/opt/atlassian/crowd/demo-webapp/crowd.properties
/opt/atlassian/crowd/client/conf/crowd.properties
{code}
fields.summary: Password reset emails have wrong base url

fields.description:
Interestingly enough there is already a knowledge base entry about this: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFKB/LDAP+User+Unable+to+Login+to+Confluence+due+to+Membership+in+Restricted+Group

It explains it all, but here is a summary as I understand it anyway:
* user attempts to authenticate (via embedded Crowd)
* user belongs to a list groups in LDAP
* the username/password configured to link said LDAP directory doesn't have sufficient right to access some of the group

This means somehow some membership are returned as {{null}}, and when we try to use {{ImmutableList.copyOf}} : _kaboom_

Here is a stack trace:

{noformat}
java.lang.NullPointerException: at index 23
    at com.google.common.collect.ImmutableList.checkElementNotNull(ImmutableList.java:318)
    at com.google.common.collect.ImmutableList.construct(ImmutableList.java:309)
    at com.google.common.collect.ImmutableList.copyFromCollection(ImmutableList.java:302)
    at com.google.common.collect.ImmutableList.copyOf(ImmutableList.java:260)
    at com.google.common.collect.ImmutableList.copyOf(ImmutableList.java:230)
    at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.MicrosoftActiveDirectory.findGroupMembershipNames(MicrosoftActiveDirectory.java:368)
    at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.RFC4519Directory.searchGroupRelationshipsWithGroupTypeSpecified(RFC4519Directory.java:447)
    at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.SpringLDAPConnector.searchGroupRelationships(SpringLDAPConnector.java:1499)
    at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory.updateGroupsMembershipOnLogin(DbCachingRemoteDirectory.java:347)
    at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory.authenticateAndUpdateInternalUser(DbCachingRemoteDirectory.java:283)
com.atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory.performAuthenticationAndUpdateAttributes(DbCachingRemoteDirectory.java:189)
    at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory.authenticate(DbCachingRemoteDirectory.java:161)
    at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.directory.DirectoryManagerGeneric.authenticateUser(DirectoryManagerGeneric.java:292)
    at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.application.ApplicationServiceGeneric.authenticateUser(ApplicationServiceGeneric.java:142)
    at com.atlassian.crowd.embedded.core.CrowdServiceImpl.authenticate(CrowdServiceImpl.java:68)
{noformat}

h3.Workaround
Make sure that both the "*Use the User Membership Attribute*" and "*Use memberOf for group membership*" options are *disabled*
fields.summary: LDAP user unable to Login to application due to membership in restricted group

fields.description:
Since CWD-3872, Crowd has a recovery mode.

It is possible that some admin may forget to switch off the recovery mode, and that may lead to problems in the future. To simplify diagnosing this case, Crowd should log a message when it's running in recovery mode, and possibly include that in the support information too.
fields.summary: Include in the logs and/or support information whether Crowd is running in recovery mode

fields.description:
If the user belongs to a read-only directory, the user cannot modify its profile via the Crowd user console. Any attempt to change the profile or the password will fail.

Prevent this error by hiding or disabling these options if the user is logged in through a read-only directory.
fields.summary: The Crowd user console should hide the profile update actions if the directory is read-only

fields.description: The new openid server at /v2 needs to talk to Crowd to fetch the users; when that fails due to invalid credentials (or ip address restrictions), the error will be logged at debug; it'd be more helpful to log that as an error.
fields.summary: New crowd openid server should not log 403 errors at debug

fields.description:
Crowd's REST client can take proxy configuration from the {{crowd.properties}} files:

{noformat}
http.proxy.host=
http.proxy.port=
http.proxy.username=
http.proxy.password=
{noformat}

These mirror the Java system properties:

{noformat}
http.proxyHost
http.proxyPort
http.proxyUser
http.proxyPassword
{noformat}

However, there is no equivalent of {{http.nonProxyHosts}}, the hosts that should be excluded from the proxy.

Rather than extending the Crowd configuration properties, configure the HTTP client so that it will fall back to using system properties when no {{http.proxy.host}} is set in the {{crowd.properties}}.
fields.summary: Crowd REST client ignores http.nonProxyHosts

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 29 July 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Crowd team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-server-bug-fix-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication.

Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Crowd Team
{panel}

fields.description:
Crowd 2.7 and 2.8 can take significantly longer than earlier versions of Crowd to authenticate a user due to copying over the group memberships on authentication. This is most apparent when authenticating in large, deeply nested LDAP directories.

I would be good to improve the login time.
fields.summary: Improve authentication performance when copying groups on login

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When a Crowd SSO session expires, and a token needs to be revalidated, the http-client will fire off a request to Crowd even if there's a pending request for another thread. This creates excessive traffic (resulting in a performance hit) and can lead to deadlocks (an outage) if there's no worker thread available to handle it if there is a reverse-proxy such as Apache serving requests in front of Crowd.

This means every single request from the client will fetch the token, and can result in a huge surge in the number of active threads (connection storm). If there's limitations in the http-client for the number of max threads (say 20 in JIRA) it also means a number of threads will block waiting for the connection pool to become available.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

This occurs when the Crowd SSO session expires, and the client makes a web request.

h3. Expected Results

The flood of requests to Crowd does not occur.

h3. Actual Results

Multiple requests to Crowd for the token will be made, creating a huge increase in the number of active threads. This can also result in:

* The product making requests to Crowd (such as JIRA) blocks on multiple threads as the http-client can max out on the active connections (in JIRA this is 20).
* If there is a reverse-proxy between the product and Crowd, that can run also out of worker threads. This can result in a deadlock and an outage on the application.
* If Crowd is running behind HTTPS, and is version 2.8.2 or lower, it is possible only 2 concurrent connections are allowed due to CWD-4337. This will significantly increase the time taken for the threads to complete processing, as Crowd is only serving 2 requests at a time (and JIRA may have >100 requesting a response from Crowd).
* If Crowd's base URL doesn't have a port (e.g.: http://crowd.atlassian.com) it's also possible it may only be serving 2 requests at a time due to CWD-4096.

As long as a deadlock does not occur it is possible the application communicating with Crowd can return to stability once the client threads receive the token, as the connection storm passes. The length of time can be exacerbated due to various conditions (interim proxy / CWD-4337). 

h3. Verification

Threads similar to the below may be an indication that this problem is occurring:

h3. Workaround

* Upgrading Crowd to address CWD-4337 will increase the number of active connections it can handle, mitigating the problem. This will also fix CWD-4096.
* Increase the maximum clients on the reverse-proxy, or bypass it completely (update the application communicating with Crowd to access on a port that is not forwarded through a proxy).
* Disable SSO in the application communicating with Crowd.
* Make sure you have _session.validationinterval=2_ in crowd.properties, that should disable check for each request 
** see related CWD-2647
fields.summary: Crowd http-client token validation can trigger a flood of requests

fields.description:
The classic CrowdID "v1" server can be configured to distribute its state using Redis.

The "v2" server ignores that configuration and always stores the associations in memory.
fields.summary: CrowdID v2 does not use the Redis association store

fields.description:
*Bug Description*

When "Enabled Aliasing" option is ticked, user with alias unable to login to Crowd console even if they configured to do so. Additionally, if an administrator user has an alias added, *all* administrator access is lost.

*How to Replicate*

# Access "Crowd" application under the application tab
# Under the "Option" tab, tick the "Enabled Aliasing"
# Add a new alias into one of the user
# Set the user directory that the above user registered at "Allow all to authenticate" option to "False"
# Ensure that the group of the user listed under the "Group" tab
# Try to login into Crowd console using that user
# Crowd will not allow the user to login to "Administrator Console"

*Additional Way to Replicate*
# Access "Crowd" application under the application tab
# Under the "Option" tab, tick the "Enabled Aliasing"
# add an administrator user to Crowd
# Add a new alias into this user
# User loses all administrator access 

*Workaround*
1. Remove alias from the user
OR
2. Disable aliasing from the database
{code:sql}
update cwd_application_attribute set attribute_value="false" where application_id=2 and attribute_name="aliasingEnabled";
{code}
fields.summary: User Unable to Login to Crowd Console due to Alias

fields.description:
*Bug Description*

Crowd 2.8 does not allow addition of group from the lower order directory of an application. This feature is important for Crowd administrator to be able to restrict user authentication to specific group(s).

*How to Replicate*

# Access one of your pre-configured application
# Add a new associated directory into the directory list of the application
# Under the "Group" tab try to add a new group from the lower order directory

*How to workaround*

# Place the directory of the group that you wish to add into the highest order temporarily. 
# Add the group that you wish
# Revert the order of the directory
fields.summary: Adding Groups from Lower Order Directory is Not Possible

fields.description:
*Specific use-case:*
Given a Microsoft-centric setup where users' email addresses are managed by Microsoft Exchange, which is tied into the same Active Directory instance Crowd is configured to synchronize from.

In this setup, users' email addresses are stored in a multi-valued LDAP attribute named {{proxyAddresses}} like so:

{code}
proxyAddresses: smtp:barbara@contoso.com
proxyAddresses: SMTP:Barbara.Sankovic@contoso.com
proxyAddresses: sip:barbara.sankovic@contoso.com
proxyAddresses: other:stuff
{code}

The primary email address which is usually (_but not always_ and therein lies the issue) found in the {{mail}} attribute is stored as the entry in {{proxyAddresses}} that starts with *SMTP:* (note the colon).

This request is to add support to the core LDAP library in Crowd to support an expression to use during LDAP sync, something like {{ldap-multivalue-field\[criteria\]}} and get the specified value from the collection -- for example {{proxyAddresses\[SMTP:\]}} which returns {{Barbara.Sankovic@contoso.com}}.
fields.summary: Support for use of value from multi-valued LDAP attribute

fields.description:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Integrating+Crowd+with+Spring+Security

It doesn't look like the specific instructions have been updated since Crowd 2.5.0. Instructions should be checked in particular for correctness in terms of locations of files, names of files, versions, and completeness of configuration information.
fields.summary: "Integrating Crowd with Spring Security" documentation is out of date

fields.description: {{RemoteCrowdDirectory}}'s {{addUser(final UserTemplateWithAttributes user, ...}} does not pass attributes through.
fields.summary: Attributes for new user creation are not passed through RemoteCrowdDirectory

fields.description:
Currently we need to change the Crowd base-url by modifying the crowd.properties file, which is not very _friendly_.

I guess that allowing users to change the Crowd base-url through the UI, just like we do on other Atlassian applications, would be awesome.
fields.summary: Change base-url through the UI
JIRA User Import PreparedStatementCallback; bad SQL grammar

fields.description: The fix for CWD-2739 used reflection to work with Java 6 and Java 7. As Crowd no longer supports Java 7 that code can be simplified.
fields.summary: Make SSLParameters changes directly, rather than through reflection

fields.description:
During the startup of this fresh install I am seeing the following, where spring doens't seem to find the jdbc.properties files, then as a result the attempt to create the schema etc fails as the dialect for hibernate hasn't been set:

{noformat}
INFO: Deploying configuration descriptor /opt/atlassian-crowd-2.8.0/apache-tomcat/conf/Catalina/localhost/openidserver.xml
2014-12-17 18:08:44,164 localhost-startStop-1 WARN [springframework.context.support.PropertySourcesPlaceholderConfigurer] Could not load properties from URL [file:${crowd.openid.home}/jdbc.properties]: ${crowd.openid.home}/jdbc.properties (No such file or directory)
2014-12-17 18:08:44,165 localhost-startStop-1 WARN [springframework.context.support.PropertySourcesPlaceholderConfigurer] Could not load properties from URL [file:${crowd.openid.home}/crowd.properties]: ${crowd.openid.home}/crowd.properties (No such file or directory)
2014-12-17 18:08:44,165 localhost-startStop-1 WARN [springframework.context.support.PropertySourcesPlaceholderConfigurer] Could not load properties from URL [file:${crowd.openid.properties}]: ${crowd.openid.properties} (No such file or directory)
2014-12-17 18:08:45,424 localhost-startStop-1 ERROR [hibernate.tool.hbm2ddl.SchemaUpdate] HHH000388: Unsuccessful: create table ADDRESSRESTRICTION (ID bigint not null, `ADDRESS` varchar(255) not null, primary key (ID)) type=InnoDB
2014-12-17 18:08:45,424 localhost-startStop-1 ERROR [hibernate.tool.hbm2ddl.SchemaUpdate] You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MySQL server version for the right syntax to use near 'type=InnoDB' at line 5
{noformat}

I'd previously executed the build.sh per the instructions

{noformat}
cmuser@vm-lin-4 atlassian-crowd-2.8.0]$ ./build.sh
Buildfile: build.xml

init:

assistant:
Changing Tomcat's connector port to 8095
Changing Tomcat's shutdown port to 8020
Configuring the Crowd console
Updating crowd.properties: crowd-webapp/WEB-INF/classes
Updating property file: /opt/atlassian-crowd-2.8.0/crowd-webapp/WEB-INF/classes/crowd.properties
Configuring the Demo application
Updating crowd.properties: demo-webapp/WEB-INF/classes
Updating property file: /opt/atlassian-crowd-2.8.0/demo-webapp/WEB-INF/classes/crowd.properties
Configuring the OpenID server application
Updating crowd.properties: crowd-openidserver-webapp/WEB-INF/classes
Updating property file: /opt/atlassian-crowd-2.8.0/crowd-openidserver-webapp/WEB-INF/classes/crowd.properties
Configuring the OpenID hibernate configuration
Updating the HibernateDialect and TransactionFactory in crowd-openidserver-webapp/WEB-INF/classes/jdbc.properties
Updating property file: /opt/atlassian-crowd-2.8.0/crowd-openidserver-webapp/WEB-INF/classes/jdbc.properties

{noformat}

and the jdbc.properties seems to have the correct content (MySQL InnoDB dialect, etc) , it's just not found for some reason.

{noformat}
#Wed Dec 17 18:11:16 EST 2014
hibernate.max_fetch_depth=1
hibernate.dialect=org.hibernate.dialect.MySQLInnoDBDialect
hibernate.show_sql=false
hibernate.jdbc.batch_size=0
hibernate.format_sql=true
hibernate.connection.datasource=java\:comp/env/jdbc/CrowdIDDS
hibernate.transaction.factory_class=org.hibernate.transaction.JDBCTransactionFactory
{noformat}
fields.summary: jdbc.properties not found during OpenID Server deploy

fields.description:
In JIRA Service Desk, it would be useful if on authentication from the customer portal there could be a way to ignore the auto adding of default groups (delegated LDAP with copy on login for example).

Perhaps an extra parameter can be included in the login request, that if present will tell Crowd to not auto add any groups.

However, if the same LDAP user was then to login through JIRA itself, they should still be updated by being auto-added to the configured default groups
fields.summary: Can authentication be told to ignore auto adding default groups

fields.description:
This issue seems to happen when large groups synchronization timed out and it seems that Crowd then remove the users from the cache as a result.

This is issue can be resolved after restarting Crowd and  also a full sync have to be performed for users to be able to login again.
fields.summary: synchronization of large groups in Crowd timeout and starts to remove users from cache

fields.description: From an external report. The 'User Directory' config pages in Confluence/JIRA display the plaintext of the password in the source (use the Chrome Inspector on a Confluence/JIRA instance that has a Crowd LDAP password already set). Please see attached screenshots.
fields.summary: Password available in plaintext in JIRA/Confluence config

fields.description:
I wanted to use the Crowd Apache Connector on Amazon EC2 instances with Amazon Linux. Atlassian does not provide the binary for the Amazon Linux, so I found I need to build it from the source. I tried the build procedure where I encountered some small problems. Here I want to share what I found, and how I could manage it.

Given:
Crowd Apache Connector version: http://downloads.atlassian.com/software/crowd/downloads/cwdapache/mod_authnz_crowd-2.2.2.tar.gz
Amazon EC2 OS version: Amazon Linux AMI 2014.09.1 (HVM) - ami-4985b048

I followed the instruction described in [Installing the Crowd Apache Connector on other UNIX-Like Systems|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Installing+the+Crowd+Apache+Connector+on+Other+UNIX-Like+Systems].

1. I opened a terminal on the EC2 instance, change to a suitable working directory, and enter the following command:
{noformat}
$ mkdir ~/cwdapache
$ cd ~/cwdapache
$ su -c "yum -y install autoconf automake gcc httpd-devel libcurl-devel libtool libxml2-devel mod_dav_svn subversion-devel"
{noformat}
  -- Success with no problem.

2. I entered the root password when prompted.
  -- Success with no problem.

3. I entered the following commands:
{noformat}
$ wget http://downloads.atlassian.com/software/crowd/downloads/cwdapache/mod_authnz_crowd-2.2.2.tar.gz
$ tar xzf mod_authnz_crowd-2.2.2.tar.gz
$ cd mod_authnz_crowd-2.2.2
{noformat}

fields.description:
When logging in as an Administrator in Crowd and editing a user, Safari and Chrome automatically replace the "username" field of Crowd to the logged-in username of the Administrator. 

This has been happening for a number of revisions of the browsers, so it's my guess that both Apple and Google are not going to change this behavior, it would be really useful if Crowd would not allow this behavior such that the  field name is not automatically being replaced with the administrator's email address on any edit. 

Screenshot attached, wherein the administrator's email is replacing that username when only viewing a user's page.
fields.summary: Disable Autocomplete in Safari and Chrome in User Editing
In Data Center products directory synchronisation can be initiated from multiple nodes

fields.description:
Crowd throws an error when syncing with LDAP directories containing CNF attributes. 

{code}
[atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingDirectoryPoller] Error occurred while refreshing the cache for directory [ XXXXX ].
org.springframework.ldap.InvalidNameException: cn=XXXXXXXXXXXXX
cnf:XXXXXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXXXXXXXX,ou=XXXXX,ou=XXXX,dc=XXXXX,dc=XXXXXX: [LDAP: error code 34 - 0000208F: NameErr: DSID-031001F7, problem 2006 (BAD_NAME), data 8349
{code}

According to this [Microsoft KB|http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb727059.aspx#EAAA]: 

{quote}
Active Directory supports multimaster replication of directory objects between all domain controllers in the domain. When replication of objects results in name conflicts (two objects have the same name within the same container), the system automatically renames one of these accounts to a unique name. For example, object ABC is renamed to be *CNF:guid, where "*" represents a reserved character, "CNF" is a constant that indicates a conflict resolution, and "guid" represents a printable representation of the objectGuid attribute value.
{quote}

So the CNF is created when there is a conflict in the replication of the domain controllers and there are duplicated objects.

Crowd should gracefully handle this error. 

*NOTE* this also propagates to other Atlassian Apps that uses Crowd embedded such as JIRA and Confluence.

h3. Workaround

I can see two options in this situation:

1) Ask the LDAP administrator to remove the duplicated groups or users from the LDAP and make sure there are no other conflicts before syncing.

2) Create a filter for the users and groups objects to avoid syncing with objects that have cnf attributes.
{code}
Should become something like:

(&(objectClass=group)(!(cnf:*)))

OR 

(&(objectCategory=Group)(!(cn=*cnf:*)))
{code}

Check here for additional details on [LDAP filters.|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DEV/How+to+write+LDAP+search+filters]
fields.summary: Gracefully handle errors when syncing with LDAP directories containing CNF attributes
Update SCM Links In pom.xml

fields.description:
Crowd's acceptance test build spins up ApacheDS 1.0 as well as ApacheDS 1.5. Since those tests are of Crowd's web UI, rather than underlying LDAP tests, there's no need to split across both versions.

Consolidate on ApacheDS 1.5 so the tests pass without the separate 1.0 instance running. The LDAP integration tests will continue to run against both 1.0 and 1.5.
fields.summary: Don't use ApacheDS 1.0 in web acceptance tests

fields.description:
Although the REST client now caches (CWD-3556) it will still make a high volume of requests even when all requests are failing.

Implement exponential backoff in the case of unexpected failure (unable to connect, or 5xx errors). A request for a resource should treat the failure as cached for an increasing period of time, so the request fails immediately without adding to the load on the remote Crowd server.

This will mean that a remote Crowd server being unavailable will not result in an increase of client or network load.
fields.summary: Implement exponential backoff on failure for RestCrowdClient

fields.description:
It will be great if we can add an option to synchronize group membership of users that have already logged in to Crowd before. The synchronization should run at a specified interval. 

Crowd currently is affected by this: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-2650 . Which means that if a delegated user is added to a new group in LDAP, the user will not be added to the said group in a connected application (e.g. Confluence), *until after* the following:
# The user logs out, then logs in again to Crowd/Confluence
# The user then waits for the sync interval between Confluence and Crowd to kick in, before the user is added to the group

The issue becomes more severe if the user checks on "Remember Me" in applications like Confluence, which will mean that they would probably not have to login for a really long time, hence, not added to the new group until they do.
fields.summary: Ability to sync group memberships of Delegated directory users at intervals

h3. Symptoms

Examples:

fields.description:
h1. Reproduction

# Select "Allow all to authenticate" for a directory containing some groups under the Crowd application
# Go to the Group section for the Crowd application
# Search from groups in that directory

h1. Solution

Hide groups from any directory set to "Allow all to authenticate".
fields.summary: Groups in directories selected as "Allow all to authenticate" for the Crowd application can be added individually as well

fields.description:
Currently, when trying to add groups, the user will be offered all groups which can legally be added to the crowd application. This includes groups which have already been added. We should remove all groups already in the crowd groups when offering options for addition.

*Environment:*
Inside the Crowd Administration's "crowd" application, on a default installation,

*Steps:*
* Go to the "Groups" tab
* Click the "Add Groups" checkbox

*Result:*
The same group that is already added is offered for (re-)addition

*Expected Result:*
No groups are shown, because all available groups have already been added
fields.summary: Do not allow adding Crowd application permissions for the same groups multiple times

fields.description:
The LDAP pool configuration set in the UI doesn't have any effect. It's set too late in the startup process, so the defaults have already been set.

CWD-4070 showed the real values and set them with a system property in Tomcat's configuration. This will need to be taken further, improving the presentation of the current settings and making it easier to set new values.

Or, given the complexity, implement CWD-2790 instead.
fields.summary: LDAP pool configuration doesn't take effect

fields.description:
As a REST client, if I want to invalidate the current password of a user so the user cannot use it anymore and is forced to reset it, then I have to generate a random password string, which may or may not match the current password policy.

I'd prefer to have a REST API to invalidate a user's password that is guaranteed to succeed, not matter which password policy has been set.
fields.summary: As a REST client, I want to invalidate a user's password

fields.description: The Asynchronous REST client does not accept non-empty responses when it creates a user. Recent versions of Crowd (since 2.8.0) return the user that has been just created and causes the client to fail when it processes the response, although the operation is actually executed in the server.
fields.summary: Create user operation fails to talk to new Crowd server

fields.description:
Since configurable directory aggregation, {{searchNestedGroupRelationships}} promotes queries for {{String.class}} to queries for {{User.class}} or {{Group.class}} in order to get the directory ID.

For an RFC 2307 directory, this means that getting all memberships will make:

* One query to get all the groups
* One query for each group to get the members
* One query for each member

This can be implemented more efficiently to eliminate the final step.
fields.summary: Membership queries for user/group names end up fetching the underlying entity

fields.description:
Found while investigating [HOT-23041|https://ops.atlassian.com/jira/browse/HOT-23041].

When a password fails to validate the {{validateCredential}} method does not indicate in the exception message which of the {{PasswordConstraint}}'s was not met. It only adds the {{passwordComplexityMessage}}, which is an optional administrator-selected message that won't tell us exactly why the password doesn't pass.

We need to at least include the name/description of the constraint in the {{InvalidCredentialException}} instance that is thrown.
fields.summary: InternalDirectoryUtilsImpl.validateCredential masks the cause of InvalidCredentialException

fields.description:
When a group appears in multiple directories, only the top-most directory's group can be added to Crowd's application groups.

h4. Environment:
In Crowd, Ensure there are two directories ({{dir1}}, {{dir2}}) with the same group {{grp}}. Then, under Applications / Crowd

h4. Steps:
* On the Directories tab, add {{dir1}} and {{dir2}} to the crowd, with {{dir1}} higher than {{dir2}}
* On the Groups tab, try and add {{grp (dir2)}}

h4. Result:
{{grp (dir2)}} does not appear, even though {{grp (dir1)}} does appear.

h4. Expected Result:
{{grp (dir2)}} exists as well as {{grp (dir1)}}.

h4. Notes:
* This doesn't happen for other applications, only Crowd.
* Groups under directories which have "Allow all to Authenticate" should also not show up.

h4. Workaround:
If you need to add a group that is affected by this issue, temporarily switch the directory order so that the one you'd like to add from is at the top. Add the group, and switch the directory order back.
fields.summary: Groups in multiple directories mapped to the Crowd application can only be added from the first directory they exist in
